tool.name: Phenolopy_Metrics

param.name: in_raw_nc_path
param.dialogReference:
A raw satellite data NetCDF generated by the COG Fetch module. Requires x, y, time and satellite band variables.

Note: three or more years is required to perform GDV Likelihood modelling.

param.name: out_metrics_nc_path
param.dialogReference: The folder location and filename of the output NetCDF file containing phenometrics data.

param.name: in_use_all_dates
param.displayname: Use median of all input images
param.dialogReference: Whether or not to use a median of all available within the input raw satellite data NetCDF. Can be useful to reduce potential variation from cross-year seasonal influences.

param.name: in_specific_years
param.dialogReference: The specific year to use if a median of all available images within the input raw satellite NetCDF is not checked. Only the year set here will be used in the phenolopy analysis and output to the phenometrics NetCDF.

param.name: in_veg_idx
param.expression: MAVI | NDVI | EVI | SAVI | MSAVI | SLAVI | kNDVI | TCG
param.dialogReference:
The vegetation index in which to represent vegetation greenness within the study area. The following vegetation indices are available:

- NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index)

- EVI (Enhanced Vegetation Index)

- SAVI (Soil-Adjusted Vegetation Index)

- MSAVI (Modified Soil-Adjusted Vegetation Index)

- SLAVI (Specific Leaf Area Vegetation Index)

- MAVI (Moisture-Adjusted Vegetation Index)

- kNDVI (Non-linear Normalized Vegetation Index)

- TCG (Tasselled Cap Greenness)

The default index is set to MAVI, which performs well in the Pilbara region of Western Australia.

param.name: in_resampling_interval
param.dialogReference:
The resampling interval used to create an equally spaced time-series required of Phenolopy. Options include:

- Weekly: imagery is resampled to one image every seven days. Recommended only for Sentinel 2 data.

- Bi-monthly: imagery is resampled to one image every 14 days. Recommended for Landsat or Sentinel 2 data.

- Monthly: imagery is resampled to one image every month. Recommended only for Landsat data.

param.name: in_metrics
param.expression: POS: Peak of season | MOS: Middle of season | VOS: Valley of season | BSE: Base of season | AOS: Amplitude of season | SOS: Start of season | EOS: End of season | LOS: Length of season | ROI: Rate of increase | ROD: Rate of decrease | LIOS: Long integral of season | SIOS: Short integral of season | LIOT: Long integral of total | SIOT: Short integral of total
param.dialogReference:
The phenological metrics generated during the analysis and output to the Phenolopy NetCDF. Available metrics include:

- POS (Peak of Season): Highest vegetation value and time of season.

- MOS (Middle of Season): Mean vegetation value and time of values in top 80% of season.

- VOS (Valley of Season): Lowest vegetation value and time of season.

- BSE (Base): Mean of the lowest vegetation values in season.

- SOS (Start of Season): Vegetation value and time at the start of season.

- EOS (End of season): Vegetation value and time at the end of season.

- LOS (Length of Season): Length of time (number of days) between the start and end of season.

- ROI (Rate of Increase): The rate of vegetation "green up" at the beginning of season.

- ROD (Rate of Decrease): The rate of vegetation "green down" at the end of season.

- AOS (Amplitude of Season): The amplitude of vegetation values for season.

- SIOS (Short Integral of Season): Represents the seasonally active vegetation and provides a larger value for herbaceous vegetation cover and smaller value for evergreen vegetation cover.

- LIOS (Long Integral of Season): Represents the total productivity of vegetation when in season.

- SIOT (Short Integral of Total): Represents total vegetation productivity throughout the season, and provides a larger value for herbaceous vegetation cover and smaller value for evergreen vegetation cover.

- LIOT (Long Integral of Total): Represents the total productivity of vegetation throughout the season.

param.name: in_calc_nos
param.dialogReference:
Whether to calculate Number of Seasons (NOS) detected at each pixel. NOS is defined as the number of prominent peaks in the vegetation across the analysis year.

Note: this method is slow.

param.name: in_method_type
param.expression: Median of slope | First of slope | Absolute value | Seasonal amplitude | Relative amplitude
param.dialogReference:
The method used to derive the start and end of season. The available options include:

- First of slope: lowest vegetation value of slope defines SOS/EOS (i.e. first/last lowest value).

- Median of slope: middle vegetation value of slope defines SOS/EOS(i.e. median value).

- Seasonal amplitude: uses a percentage of the amplitude starting from the base value to find SOS/EOS.

- Absolute value: users defined absolute value in vegetation index units is used to define SOS/EOS.

- Relative amplitude: mean of peak and base, and a factor of that area, are used to define SOS/EOS.

The first of slope and median of slope are the recommended methods.

param.name: in_peak_metric
param.expression: POS: Peak of season | MOS: Middle of season
param.dialogReference:
The metric used to define the highest point of the vegetation phenological signal. Options include:

- POS (Peak of Seasons): The highest value in the whole time series

- MOS (Middle of Season): Average of the highest value to the left and right side of the POS.

POS is the recommended metric.

param.name: in_base_metric
param.expression: VOS: Valley of season | BSE: Base of season
param.dialogReference:
The metric used to define the lowest point of the vegetation phenological signal. Options include:

- VOS (Valley of Seasons): The lowest value in the whole time series

- BSE (Base): Average of the lowest value to the left and right side of the POS.

VOS is the recommended metric.

param.name: in_threshold_side
param.dialogReference:
Whether the SOS/EOS value threshold calculation should be the min value of left/right slope (one_sided) only, or use the BSE or VOS value (two_sided) calculated earlier.

Two-sided is recommended.

param.name: in_seasonal_amp_factor
param.dialogReference:
A value between 0 and 1 which is used to increase or decrease the amplitude threshold for the seasonal amplitude method. A factor closer to 0 results in SOS/EOS nearer to minimum value, a factor closer to 1 results in SOS/EOS closer to peak of season.

Note: only used during seasonal amplitude method.

param.name: in_absolute_value
param.dialogReference:
Defines the absolute value in units of the vegetation index to which SOS/EOS is defined. The part of the vegetation phenological signal that the absolute value intersects with will be the SOS/EOS value and time.

Note: only used during absolute value method.

param.name: in_smooth_method
param.dialogReference:
The smoothing algorithm to apply to the time series. The options include:

- Savitsky-Golay filter: a smoothing algorithm that intends to keep the general structure and peaks and troughs of the signal.

- Symmetrical Gaussian: applies a simple symmetrical gaussian.

Note: Savitsky-Golay is recommended.

param.name: in_savitsky_window_length
param.dialogReference:
The length of the Savitsky-Golay filter window (i.e., the number of coefficients). The length must be a positive odd integer.

The higher the window length, the more smoothing is applied.

param.name: in_savitsky_polyorder
param.dialogReference: The order of the polynomial used to fit the samples (i.e., poly order). The poly order value must be less than window length.

param.name: in_gaussian_sigma
param.dialogReference: Standard deviation for Gaussian kernel. The standard deviations of the Gaussian filter must be provided as a single number between 1-9.

param.name: in_outlier_method
param.dialogReference:
The outlier detection method to apply to the time series. The median method detects outliers by calculating if values in pixel timeseries deviate more than a maximum deviation (cutoff) from the median in a moving window (half window width = number of values per year / 7) and it is lower than the mean value of its immediate neighbors minus the cutoff or it is larger than the highest value of its immediate neighbors. The cutoff is the standard deviation of the entire time-series times a factor given by the user.

The second method, Z-Score, is similar but uses a Z-Test to detect whether outliers are signficicantly (i.e. via p-value) outside the population values.

param.name: in_user_factor
param.dialogReference:
A value between 0 to 10 which is used to 'multiply' the threshold cutoff. A higher factor value results in few outliers (i.e. only the most extreme outliers).

The default factor is 2.

param.name: in_zscore_pvalue
param.dialogReference:
The p-value for Z-Score method. A higher p-value (i.e. 0.01) results in fewer outliers being removed, whereas a lower p-value (i.e 0.1) results in more.

The default is a p-value of 0.05.

param.name: in_fmask_flags
param.expression: NoData | Valid | Cloud | Shadow | Snow | Water
param.dialogReference:
Classes captured within the OA measurement band provided for each satellite image via the DEA Fmask algorithm.

Only the selected pixel classes will be returned, whilst all others will be set to NoData (i.e., masked out).

param.name: in_max_cloud
param.dialogReference:
The maximum percentage of cloud cover existing per satellite image before it is discarded from analysis.

A value of 0 will return all satellite data with no cloud cover. A value of 10 will discard all satellite data with 11% or more cloud presence. A value of 100 will return all images regardless.

param.name: in_add_result_to_map
param.dialogReference: Whether to visualise the results to the currently active map once modelling is complete or not.

tool.summary:
Phenolopy (phenology + python) is a python-based library for analyzing satellite timeseries data. Phenolopy has been designed to investigate the seasonality of satellite timeseries data and their relationship with dynamic vegetation properties such as phenology and temporal growth patterns. The temporal domain holds important information about short- and long-term changes within vegetation lifecycles.

Phenolopy is heavily based on the concept and methodology behind the TIMESAT software (see http://web.nateko.lu.se/timesat/timesat.asp). Unlike TIMESAT, however, Phenolopy has been designed to be a light-weight, easy to use python library that can be applied to any satellite imagery stack (e.g. MODIS, Landsat and Sentinel satellite sensors). Phenolopy also provides enhanced tools to resample timeseries data to different temporal intervals (e.g. weekly, bi-monthly or monthly spacing).

Phenolopy can be applied to derive numerous phenometrics from satellite imagery, as presented in Figure 1 below. These phenometrics can be derived for any type of land phenomena, including crop vegetation, native vegetation, and even moisture data. That said, the key target is vegetation.
